cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history, philosophy, and practice of the major religions of the world, including Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism and Taoism.
cmCourseInfo.title: World Religions
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: RLG280Y1,RLGA01H3,RLGA02H3. Note: RLGA01H3 and RLGA02H3 taken together are equivalent to RLG100Y1. Note: RLG101H5 is not equivalent to RLG100Y1Y

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to topics in the study of Religion. Topics will vary by semester and year. Check the department website for upcoming topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introducing Religion

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Jan. 5, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to topics in the study of Religion. Topics will vary by semester and year. Check the department website for upcoming topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introducing Religion

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the discipline of the study of religion. This course surveys methods in the study of religion and the history of the discipline in order to prepare students to be majors or specialists in the study of religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Study of Religion (formerly RLG200Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Open to Religion Specialists and Majors

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the religious tradition of the Jews, from its ancient roots to its modern crises. Focus on great ideas, thinkers, books, movements, sects, and events in the historical development of Judaism through its four main periods - biblical, rabbinic, medieval, and modern.
cmCourseInfo.title: Judaism

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the Christian religious tradition as it has developed from the 1st century C.E. to the present and has been expressed in teachings, institutions, social attitudes, and the arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Christianity

cmCourseInfo.description: The faith and practice of Islam: historical emergence, doctrinal development, and interaction with various world cultures. Note: this course is offered alternatively with NMC283Y1, to which it is equivalent.
cmCourseInfo.title: Islam

cmCourseInfo.description: A historical and thematic introduction to the Hindu religious tradition as embedded in the socio-cultural structures of India.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hinduism

cmCourseInfo.description: The development, spread, and diversification of Buddhist traditions from southern to northeastern Asia, as well as to the West.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhism

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the psychological approaches to aspects of religion such as religious experience, doctrine, myth and symbols, ethics and human transformation. Attention will be given to phenomenological, psychoanalytic, Jungian, existentialist, and feminist approaches.
cmCourseInfo.title: Psychology of Religion

cmCourseInfo.description: Anthropological study of the supernatural in small-scale non-literate societies. A cross-cultural examination of systems of belief and ritual focusing on the relationship between spiritual beings and the cosmos as well as the rights and obligations which arise therefrom. Among the topics covered are: myth and ritual; shamanism and healing; magic, witchcraft and sorcery; divination; ancestor worship.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Religion (formerly RLG212Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of pilgrimage has become increasingly prominent in anthropology and religious studies in recent decades. Why should this be? This course provides some answers while engaging in a cross cultural survey and analysis of pilgrimage practices. We also explore whether research into pilgrimage has wider theoretical significance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pilgrimage as Idea and Practice

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the analysis of ethical problems in the context of the religious traditions of the West. Abortion, euthanasia, poverty, environmental degradation, militarism, sex, marriage, and the roles of men and women.
cmCourseInfo.title: Problems in Religious Ethics

cmCourseInfo.description: Course explores issues at the intersection of religion and science which may include such topics as evolution and the assessment of its religious significance by different traditions, conceptions of God held by scientists (theism, pantheism, panentheism), ethical issues raised by scientific or technological developments ( cloning or embryonic stem cell research), philosophical analysis of religious and scientific discourses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Science (formerly RLG231Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The role of film as a mediator of thought and experience concerning religious worldviews. The ways in which movies relate to humanitys quest to understand itself and its place in the universe are considered in this regard, along with the challenge which modernity presents to this task. Of central concern is the capacity of film to address religious issues through visual symbolic forms.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Film

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on the interactions, both positive and negative, between religion and popular culture. We look at different media (television, advertising, print) as they represent and engage with different religious traditions, identities, and controversies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Popular Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: September 8th, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of gender as a category in the understanding of religious roles, symbols, rituals, deities, and social relations. Survey of varieties of concepts of gender in recent feminist thought, and application of these concepts to religious life and experience. Examples will be drawn from a variety of religious traditions and groups, contemporary and historical.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion, Gender, and Sexuality (formerly RLG314H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Sept 14, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: Some topic of central interest to students of religion, treated on a once-only basis. For details of this years offering, consult the Departments current undergraduate handbook.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to early Christian writings, including the 'New Testament,' examined within the historical context of the first two centuries. No familiarity with Christianity or the New Testament is expected.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Christian Writings I

courses.name: Karma and Dharma in Indic Tradition

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 15, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: A comparative study of the development of ethical perspectives in Hinduism, Buddhism, and Jainism, concluding with a discussion of contemporary moral issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Karma and Dharma in Indic Tradition

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Students in LEC0101 must select TUT0101

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Students in LEC0101 must select TUT0101

cmCourseInfo.description: The first semester of an introduction to Classical Sanskrit for beginners. Students build grammar and vocabulary, and begin to read texts in Sanskrit. Complete beginners are welcome. Two sections of the course will be offered: an on-campus class meeting and an online section via live webinar participation. The final exam will require attendance on the St. George campus, or in another authorized exam centre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sanskrit I (formerly RLG260Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
LEC0101 (in-class) students must sign up for TUT0101 (in-class). LEC9901 (online) students must sign up for TUT9901 (online tutorial).

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to Classical Tibetan language for beginners. Development of basic grammar and vocabulary, with readings of simple texts. This is an online course. Lectures will be delivered via the web and mandatory tutorials will require live webinar participation. The final exam will require attendance on the St. George campus, or in another authorized exam centre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Tibetan I (formerly RLG261Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The second semester of an introduction to Classical Tibetan language course for beginners. Continued work on grammar and vocabulary, advancing to reading texts. This is an online course. Lectures will be delivered via the web and mandatory tutorials will require live webinar participation. The final exam will require attendance on the St. George campus, or in another authorized exam centre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Tibetan II (formerly RLG261Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG261H1

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Students in LEC0101 must select TUT0101

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Students in LEC0101 must select TUT0101

cmCourseInfo.description: The second semester of an introduction to Classical Sanskrit for beginners. Students continue to build grammar and vocabulary, and use that knowledge to read texts in Sanskrit. Two sections of the course will be offered: an on-campus class meeting and an online section via live webinar participation. The final exam will require attendance on the St. George campus, or in another authorized exam centre.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Sanskrit II (formerly RLG260Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG260H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
LEC0101 (in-class) students must sign up for TUT0101 (in-class). LEC9901 (online) students must sign up for TUT9901 (online tutorial).

cmCourseInfo.description: An alternative version of the content covered by RLG100Y1
cmCourseInfo.title: World Religions: A Comparative Study
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: for students in second year or higher who cannot or do not wish to take a further 100-level course. Students attend the RLG100Y1 lectures and tutorials but are expected to produce more substantial and more sophisticated written work
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText:
and are required to submit an extra written assignment.

"

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rop. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

cmCourseInfo.description: Systematic analysis of Freud’s main writings on religion, studied within the context of central concepts and issues in psychoanalysis such as: the Oedipus Complex, the meaning and function of symbols, the formation of the ego and the superego, and the relations between the individual and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sigmund Freud on Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG211Y1/RLG211H1; see note above for general Prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Theories of the self that involve the constitutive role of language in its various forms. Problems of socially-conditioned worldviews and sense of self as related to discourse. Myth, symbol, metaphor, and literary arts as vehicles for personality development and self-transformation along religious lines.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language, Symbols, Self
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Religions are constituted by material forms, including bodies, shrines, films, icons, and ‘ kitsch’. Anti-material impulses have also prompted many religious impulses, involving forms of iconoclasm that ironically demonstrate the power of objects. What is at stake in studying materiality? How might such a perspective transform our view of religion?
cmCourseInfo.title: Material Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Museums have long collected and curated religious objects for public audiences, with missionaries as a primary collections source. Multiple visits to the Royal Ontario Museum and other museums will enable students to think critically about how museums received and presented these objects, while engaging with the challenges of museum curation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Museums and Material Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One FCE in Social Science or Humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: The course focuses on the role of religion in the genesis and development of cities, as well as the ways urbanization and immigration have transformed religious organizations and identities. Various methodologies, including ethnography, social and cultural history, and textual analysis will be considered. In some years, course projects will focus on mapping the changing significance and presence of particular religions in Toronto. Check with the department for the next scheduled focus for this course.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and the City
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: The relationship and interaction between religious and ethical norms, social and political ideals, and systems of law.The course concerns the ongoing dialectic between religious and other values, the application of religious ideas to social orders, and questions of religious and human rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Human Rights
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: three RLG or PHI/PHL half-courses and third year standing. See note above for general prerequisites

courses.name: Modern Atheism and the Critique of Religion (formerly RLG310Y1)

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room changed: September 8th, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines major classical thinkers who have contributed to the development of critical approaches to religion in the modern West, and whose theories still influence contemporary debates. We begin with the 17th century European Enlightenment and proceed to examine selected 19th and 20th century thinkers. The approaches considered are mainly philosophical, but include historical, social, and political issues as well. Authors studied include Hume, Kant, Marx, Nietzsche and others.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Atheism and the Critique of Religion (formerly RLG310Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: three RLG or PHI/PHL half-courses and third year standing. See note above for general prerequisites

courses.name: Gender, Body and Sexuality in Islam

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Dec. 12, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the role of women in Muslim societies in past and present. Topics include the status of women in the Quran and Islamic law, veiling, social change, and Islamic feminism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender, Body and Sexuality in Islam
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: see note above for general Prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the variety of ways in which religious traditions construct sanctity, articulate categories of exceptionalism, and how exceptional persons function within social systems. Consideration of gender and social status in definitions of sanctity. Focus varies from year to year, and may focus either on constructions of sanctity in one religious tradition, or comparatively, comparing and contrasting ideas of sainthood and martyrdom in Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism and/or Buddhism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Martyrs, Mystics, and Saints

cmCourseInfo.description: Religious violence and nonviolence as they emerge in the tension between strict adherence to tradition and individual actions of charismatic figures. The place of violence and nonviolence in selected faith traditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religious Violence and Nonviolence
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: RLG100Y1/280Y1; see note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Literary, historical, and rhetorical analyses of selected early Christian gospels. The gospels to be treated will vary, but each year will include a selection from the four canonical gospels and extra-canonical gospels (the Gospel of Thomas, the Gospel of Philip, the Gospel of Peter, the Gospel of Truth, infancy gospels, and fragments of Jewish-Christian gospels).
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Christian Gospels
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG241Y1; see note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of Paul’s life and thought as seen in the early Christian literature written by him (the seven undisputed letters), about him (the Acts of the Apostles, the Acts of Paul) and in his name (the six disputed NT letters).
cmCourseInfo.title: Paul of Tarsus
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG241Y1; see note for above general Prerequisites

courses.name: Roots of Early Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of selected documents of Second Temple Judaism in their historical contexts, as part of the generative matrix for both the early Jesus movement and the emergence of rabbinic Judaism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Roots of Early Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG241Y1/RLG202Y1/RLG203Y1; see note for general prerequisites

courses.name: Monsters and Others in the Christian Middle Ages

cmCourseInfo.description: A course looking at the theories about and responses to the monstrous in the European Christian Middle Ages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Monsters and Others in the Christian Middle Ages
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

courses.name: Witchcraft and Magic in Christian Tradition

cmCourseInfo.description: This course considers the history and theory of Western witchcraft, magic, and heresy in the mediaeval and early modern periods. Consideration of relevant anthropological theory, the relationship between constructions of witchcraft, the Enlightenment and the rise of science, and the role of gender in definitions of witchcraft.
cmCourseInfo.title: Witchcraft and Magic in Christian Tradition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

courses.name: Judaism in the Modern Age (formerly RLG342Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: The development and range of modern Jewish religious thought from Spinoza, Mendelssohn and Krochmal, to Cohen, Rosenzweig and Buber. Responses to the challenges of modernity and fundamental alternatives in modern Judaism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Judaism in the Modern Age (formerly RLG342Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG100Y1/RLG202Y1/RLG221H1/RLG280Y1; see note above for general Prerequisites

courses.name: Kabbala: A History of Mystical Thought in Judaism

cmCourseInfo.description: A historical study of the Kabbala and the mystical tradition in Judaism, with emphasis on the ideas of Jewish mystical thinkers and movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Kabbala: A History of Mystical Thought in Judaism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG100Y1/RLG202Y1/RLG280Y1; see note above for general Prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: The revelatory process and the textual formation of the Quran, its pre-eminent orality and its principal themes and linguistic forms; the classical exegetical tradition and some contemporary approaches to its interpretation.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Quran: An Introduction
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG100Y1/RLG204Y1/RLG224H1/RLG280Y1/NMC185Y1/NMC185H1; see note above for general Prerequisites

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Jan. 6, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will study Islam in a post-colonial framework.  It will introduce students to the work of post-colonial studies, and how critical scholarship has transformed our understanding of monolithic concepts such as modernity, the nation and Islam.  It will focus on the particular case of Islam in South Asia and the Middle East by exposing students to the transformative impact of colonialism.  It will equip students with the tools to challenge the hegemonic notion of a singular 'tradition' in Islam by tracing its lineages in the post-colony.
cmCourseInfo.title: Post-Colonial Islam
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NMC283Y1/RLG204Y1/NMC278H1; see note above for general Prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Topics in Hinduism. Themes vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Hinduism

cmCourseInfo.description: Review of grammar and the development of vocabulary with a focus on reading simple narrative prose and verse.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Sanskrit I

cmCourseInfo.description: Review of grammar and the further development of vocabulary with a focus on reading simple narrative prose and verse.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Sanskrit II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG359H1

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of different schools, texts, and issues of Hindu philosophy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hindu Philosophy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG100Y1/RLG205Y1/RLG280Y1/ ;See note above for general Prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: The course surveys the textual sources of the practices of Yoga and Ayurveda. It critically evaluates the assumption of an unbroken continuity of tradition of these practices from antiquity onwards and comes to consider what they have come to constitute as a result of modernity and globalization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Yoga and Ayurveda
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG205Y1; see note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the various schools of Tibetan Buddhism, focusing on differences in both theory and practice, with readings of Tibetan texts in translation and ethnographic studies of Buddhist practice in Tibet.
cmCourseInfo.title: Tibetan Buddhism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG206Y; see note above for general prerequisites

courses.name: Buddhism in South and Southeast Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: The course serves as an introduction to one or more Buddhist traditions still living or historically documented in South and Southeast Asia, ranging from ancient and medieval Buddhism to Buddhist modernities and including Buddhism in its local Theravada variants. Themes will vary by year; consult the departmental website for this year’s course description.
cmCourseInfo.title: Buddhism in South and Southeast Asia

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Sept 30, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: The contemporary phenomenon of religious pluralism: its historical emergence, social context and intellectual justifications. Achievements, techniques and outstanding issues in inter-religious dialogue.
cmCourseInfo.title: Pluralism and Dialogue
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: See note above for general prerequisites

cmCourseInfo.description: Special Topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics I

sections.name: LEC5101
sections.subTitle: Queering Religion: Religion in the Closet, Religion out of the Closet

cmCourseInfo.description: Special Topics.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics I

cmCourseInfo.description: Special Topics
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics II

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 19, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: An integrative capstone seminar that emphasizes iterative development of a research project, locating a research specialization within its broader disciplinary audience, and communicating the process and results of a research project to non-specialists within the study of religion.Open to Relgion Specialists and Majors only.
cmCourseInfo.title: Departmental Capstone-Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: open to 4th year  Religion Specialists and Majors

cmCourseInfo.description: A capstone seminar that emphasizes integration of the study of religion with contemporary public life in the development of a research project, locating a research specialization in relation to non-academic contexts, and communicating the process and results of a research project to non-academic audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Departmental Capstone-Practical
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: open to 4th year  Religion Specialists and Majors

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Topics in Religion
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Religion

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Topics in Religion
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Religion

cmCourseInfo.description: Few methods have been more foundational to the scholarly study of religion, or more subject to searching criticism, than the practice of comparison.  This seminar offers an advanced introduction to comparative method through close study of 4-6 recent works, from ritual studies, philosophy of religion, comparative theology and/or ethnography
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparing Religions
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced study of Immanuel Kant’s theory of religion, as developed in major writings such as Critique of Practical Reason and Religion within the Boundaries of Mere Reason. Emphasizes rational ethical criteria as the basis for analyzing the doctrines, symbols, and institutions of historical religions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Kant's Theory of Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

courses.name: Religion in the Public Sphere Service-Learning Internship

cmCourseInfo.description: For upper-year students, from any discipline. In a 40-hour community service placement, discover first-hand religion’s significance in Toronto and examine how religion manifests in public spaces, institutions, and interactions, while critically reflecting on the experience of working with professionals and their “clients” in settings where religious diversity is at play.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion in the Public Sphere Service-Learning Internship
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RPS coordinator's permission required for admission to course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Natural Law in Judaism and Christianity

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: Sept 30, 2016

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Topics in Judaism
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Judaism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to The Guide of the Perplexed by Moses Maimonides, and to some of the basic themes in Jewish philosophical theology and religion. Among topics to be considered through close textual study of the Guide: divine attributes; biblical interpretation; creation versus eternity; prophecy; providence, theodicy, and evil; wisdom and human perfection. Also to be examined are leading modern interpreters of Maimonides.
cmCourseInfo.title: Maimonides and His Modern Interpreters
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

courses.name: Words and Worship in Christian Cultures

cmCourseInfo.description: How are we to analyze the words that Christians use? And how are such words related to ritual forms? We explore techniques for the analysis of texts, while looking at forms of verbal discourse ranging from prayers, speaking in tongues, and citing the Bible to more informal narratives.
cmCourseInfo.title: Words and Worship in Christian Cultures
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT356H1/RLG212Y1 and permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

courses.name: Social History of the Jesus Movement

cmCourseInfo.description: The social setting of the early Jesus movement in Roman Palestine and the cities of the Eastern Empire. Topics will include: rank and legal status; patronalia and clientalia; marriage and divorce; forms of association outside the family; slavery and manumission; loyalty to the empire and forms of resistance.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social History of the Jesus Movement
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG241Y1 and at least one of RLG319H1 - RLG327H1; permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of specialized topics in Islam.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Islam
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: An academic legend recounts that if you ask a Newar whether he is Hindu or Buddhist the answer is yes. The course deals with the problem of how to study religions which coexist and compete with each other creating shifting coordinates of religious identification from the perspective of one specific Nepalese community.
cmCourseInfo.title: Newar Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of Instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study of specialized topics in Buddhist Studies
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Buddhism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced readings in Tibetan literature using Tibetan language. Tibetan language skills required.
cmCourseInfo.title: Readings in Tibetan

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced study in specialized topics on Hinduism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Hinduism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG205Y; Permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of Vedantic thought beginning with the classical commentaries on the Brahmasutras (such as those of Sankara, Ramanuja etc.) and ending with neo-Vedanta in the writings of Dayananda Saraswati, Sri Aurobindo and Radhakrishnan.
cmCourseInfo.title: Vedanta Through the Ages
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: RLG205Y1; RLG205H5; Instructor's permission required for admission to course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated intensive research courses supervised by faculty members of the Department. The student must obtain both a Supervisor's agreement and the Department's approval in order to register. The maximum number of Independent Research courses one may take is two full-course equivalents. Deadline for submitting applications to Department, including Supervisor's approval, is the first week of classes of the session. A full-course may be compressed into a single session or spread through two sessions; a half-course may similarly be done in either one session or across two sessions. These courses are open to majors and specialists only. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research

cmCourseInfo.description: Student-initiated intensive research courses supervised by faculty members of the Department. The student must obtain both a Supervisor's agreement and the Department's approval in order to register. The maximum number of Independent Research courses one may take is two full-course equivalents. Deadline for submitting applications to Department, including Supervisor's approval, is the first week of classes of the session. A full-course may be compressed into a single session or spread through two sessions; a half-course may similarly be done in either one session or across two sessions. These courses are open to majors and specialists only. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: please visit http://www.religion.utoronto.ca/programs/undergraduate/ for enrolment instructions. For further questions, please contact Marilyn Colaco at religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca
